stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 'Space City' level (Course 14), modeling a gramophone-shaped concert hall and a flying car. He spent time debugging custom lighting effects, discussed his game design philosophy, and detailed his collaborative workflow with team members Biobak and Zeina. A significant portion of the stream was also dedicated to his strong opposition to a potential fan-made PC port of the game.

development_findings.summary: The space city level (Course 14) will feature a two-act structure. In the first act, Shy Guys are hidden, limiting traversal. After the boss is defeated, they emerge and drive flying cars, which the player can then use to get around.
Kaze is designing a concert hall for the space city, with the idea that it should be shaped like a gramophone.
While researching for a video, Kaze discovered that the shaders used for the interactive Mario head at the start of SM64 were far more advanced than the technology used in the rest of the game.
development_findings.quote: The Goddard-related shaders. Goddard is the person that made the Mario intro scene thing. The head that you can control. And everything in there is like months or years ahead of what the Nintendo development team was doing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is skeptical that a PC port could correctly render the game, believing his custom shaders would not be supported. He argues that emulators like RT64 already provide superior features like frame interpolation.

Kaze avoids implementing complex shadows, not because it's technically impossible, but because adding them in one area would create an obligation to add them everywhere for visual consistency, which is too much work.
A fake reflection effect on a wall is achieved by moving a texture in relation to the camera's position, as a true reflection is too computationally expensive for the N64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the key to modern game design is creating an experience that feels open and non-linear to the player, even if the underlying structure is linear.
context_findings.quote: I think that's key the key to modern game design you want to make something that is linear, but isn't it?

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes when his work is praised with the caveat that he works alone and without a budget, as he feels it diminishes the work and highlights his difficult circumstances rather than the quality of the project itself.
context_findings.quote: I hate when people look at my stuff. And they're like it's impressive. And then someone else always says. Oh but he has no budget. And he works alone. And I'm just like. I have no budget. And I work alone. Isn't that like making me look bad?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong negative stance against a potential PC port of the game, believing it offers no advantages over modern emulators and will only create more support headaches and annoying questions from the community.
context_findings.quote: If I had the ability to just like slip my fingers and the PC port would be out of existence, I would do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains his philosophy on criticism, stating he enjoys playfully hating things (like Conker's Bad Fur Day) but wants others to defend them, as he feels uncomfortable if his criticism turns into a group pile-on.
context_findings.quote: I like hating on things, but I don't like if other people join me and hating on those things. Because then I feel like a bully.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals his ROM hacking work is essentially a second full-time job on top of his professional programming job. He shares that his YouTube income is modest after paying his editor, and Patreon provides the majority of his income for this work.
Kaze expresses a personal philosophy that facing adversity is necessary to feel a sense of freedom and to be able to express one's free will.
context_findings.quote: I think to express your free will as a human being, you need some amount of adversity. [...] I don't feel very free without adversity.

biobak.summary: Biobak's role is to polish Kaze's 3D models, improve their visual quality, and contribute new ideas and concepts to the game's art.
biobak.quote: Biobak goes over my models. After I'm done. And polishes them up. Brings a lot of ideas. And new concepts to the table.

biobak.summary: Kaze relies on Biobak to fix and improve his placeholder or rough 3D models, as seen with the flying car he was creating.
biobak.quote: We got Biobak. Biobak will bail me out.

badub.summary: Kaze confirms that Badub is the composer for the project, handling all the music because Kaze himself has no musical ability.
badub.quote: Yeah Badub is doing the music. I can't do music at all.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the concept art for the 'mutant Yoshi' boss planned for the space city level.
zeina.quote: This was her idea for the mutant Yoshi. That's the boss enemy here.

key_stories.title: The PC Port Controversy
key_stories.summary: Kaze vehemently objects to the idea of a PC port for RTYI, believing it's technically inferior to modern emulation and will be a source of community frustration. Despite his feelings, he acknowledges he can't prevent a fan from trying to make one, creating a point of tension between creator intent and fan desire.
key_stories.challenge: A community member, Alexado, proposed creating a PC port of RTYI, a move Kaze strongly opposes.
key_stories.process: Kaze voiced his objections on stream, arguing that modern emulators are superior and that the port would be unable to handle the game's custom shaders. He expressed frustration at the community's lack of understanding and the future support requests it would generate. Alexado appeared in chat, confirming people were already asking him about it.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has made his opposition clear but acknowledges he cannot stop Alexado from attempting the port. He is resigned to its potential existence but wants no involvement and anticipates it will cause problems.
key_stories.key_quote: If I had the ability to just like slip my fingers and the PC port would be out of existence, I would do it.

key_stories.title: The "Impressive For A Solo Dev" Compliment
key_stories.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with fans who praise his work by highlighting his lack of budget and solo effort. He explains that he views these as limitations, not strengths, and that he would prefer to have the resources to collaborate and create an even better game.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze feels that a common compliment from his fans—praising his work because he does it alone and without a budget—is actually demeaning.
key_stories.process: During the stream, Kaze explained his frustration with this specific type of praise. He argued that having resources and a team would allow him to create a better game, reframing the 'lone wolf' narrative as a negative that he has to overcome.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze clarified his perspective to the audience, revealing that he sees his lack of resources as a constraint, not a badge of honor. This provides insight into his ambitions and the practical challenges he faces.
key_stories.key_quote: I have no budget. And I work alone. Isn't that like making me look bad? Making my life more difficult. I feel like if I had money to pay people. Then I would have a better shot at being a good gamer.

key_stories.title: Designing the Flying Car
key_stories.summary: While developing the space city, Kaze needed to create a flying car. He built a rough placeholder model on stream, acknowledging its flaws but expressing confidence that his artist, Biobak, would polish it later. This incident clearly demonstrates their collaborative process where Kaze handles initial implementation and Biobak provides artistic refinement.
key_stories.challenge: The space city level requires a method of transportation for NPCs that also functions as a gameplay mechanic for the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed and modeled a flying car live on stream. He focused on the basic shape and keeping the polygon count low, experimenting with textures for details like the grill. He acknowledged the model's roughness and immediately identified that Biobak's role would be to refine it later.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a rough, low-poly model for a flying car. While functional as a placeholder, he explicitly stated that he is relying on his collaborator, Biobak, to polish the model and make it visually appealing, showcasing their team's workflow.
key_stories.key_quote: This is going to look bad. But it's fine, it's fine. We got Biobak. Biobak will bail me out.

open_questions.context: Kaze showed a concept drawing by his spouse, Zeina, for a 'mutant Yoshi' boss. He also mentioned that an unnamed collaborator, possibly Zeina, modeled the Peach, Toad, and Luigi characters.
questions: What is the creative dynamic like working with your spouse on a project this personal?
How do you and Zeina collaborate on ideas? Can you walk us through the process for the 'mutant Yoshi' boss?
What other specific artistic or design contributions has Zeina made to the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated his core design philosophy is to 'make something that is linear, but isn't it?' He applied this to the space city level design.
questions: Could you elaborate on your philosophy of 'linear, but isn't it'?
How does this principle of guided freedom influence level design throughout the rest of the game?
Which commercial games do you feel best exemplify this design philosophy?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly disclosed his income from YouTube and Patreon, framing his ROM hacking as a 'second full-time job' and wishing he had a budget to pay people.
questions: How do you manage the immense time commitment of a full-time job alongside a project as demanding as RTYI?
You mentioned wishing for a budget. If you suddenly received funding for the project, what would be the very first thing you would spend it on?
How do the financial realities of being a creator dependent on Patreon and YouTube affect the scope and direction of the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze explained the space city level has a two-act structure where the environment and available paths change after defeating a boss.
questions: What is the story behind the boss that triggers the change in the space city level? Is it the 'mutant Yoshi' Zeina designed?
How does this two-act structure impact the player's experience and the level's difficulty curve?
Are there other levels in RTYI that use a similar form of narrative progression to alter the gameplay environment?

open_questions.context: Kaze is strongly opposed to a fan-led PC port of RTYI, citing technical limitations (custom shaders) and social fatigue. A fan named Alexado intends to attempt it anyway.
questions: Can you detail the specific technical hurdles, like the custom shaders, that you believe a PC port would fail to overcome?
What is your primary motivation for creating the port, even with the original creator's reservations?
How do you plan to address the technical challenges Kaze mentioned, such as compatibility with custom shaders and renderers?
